super_gui¶

statslib¶

statslib.point.best_fit(chisq, param)[source]¶

Calculate the best-fit.

Arguments: chisq – Data column of chi-squared. param – Data column of parameter.

Returns: bestfit – The best-fit point.

statslib.point.p_value(chisq, dof)[source]¶

Calculate the pvalue.

Arguments: chisq – Data column of chi-squared. dof – Number of degrees of freedom.

Returns: pvalue – A p-value for the given chisq, dof.

statslib.point.posterior_mean(posterior, param)[source]¶

Calculate the posterior mean.

Arguments: posterior – Data column of posterior weight. param – Data column of parameter.

Returns: postmean - The posterior mean.

statslib.point.shift(bin_number, nbins)[source]¶

Modify bin numbers so that bin numbers, initially (0, nbins + 1) because numpy uses extra bins for outliers, match array indices (0, nbins - 1).

Parameters:
  • bin_number (integer) – A bin number
  • nbins (integer) – Total number of bins
Returns:

Shifted bin number
Return type:

integer
statslib.one_dim.conf_interval(chi_sq, bin_centers, alpha)[source]¶

Calculate one dimensional confidence interval.

Warning

Confidence intervals are are not contiguous. We have to specify whether each bin is inside or outside of a confidence interval.

Parameters:
  • chi_sq – Data column of profiled chi-squared
  • bin_centers – Data column of parameter at bin centers
  • alpha – Probability level

Returns named tuple: deltachisq, confint ** TODO goodify **

statslib.one_dim.credible_region(pdf, bin_centers, alpha, region)[source]¶

Calculate one-dimensional credible region. Find \(a\) such that

\[\int_{-\infnty}^{a} p(x) dx = 1 - \alpha / 2\]
Parameters:
  • pdf – Data column of marginalised posterior PDF
  • bin_centers – Data column of parameter at bin centers
  • alpha – Probability level
Region:

Upper of lower interval
Returns:

Bin center of edge of credible region
Return type:

float
statslib.one_dim.posterior_pdf(parameter, posterior, nbins=50, bin_limits=None)[source]¶

Weighted histogram of data for posterior PDF.

Parameters:
  • parameter – Data column of parameter of interest
  • posterior – Data column of posterior weight, same length as data
  • nbins (integer) – Number of bins for histogram
Bin_limits:

Bin limits for histogram
Returns:

pdf - posterior PDF - and bin_centers - centers of bins for probability distribution
Return type:

named tuple
statslib.one_dim.prof_data(parameter, chi_sq, nbins=50, bin_limits=None)[source]¶

Maximizes the likelihood in each bin to obtain the profile likelihood and profile chi-squared.

Parameters:
  • parameter – Data column of parameter of interest
  • chi_sq – Data column of chi-squared, same length as data
  • nbins (integer) – Number of bins for histogram
Bin_limits:

Bin limits for histogram
Returns:
Return type:

named tuple

plotlib¶

data_loader¶

data_loader.label_chain(data, info)[source]¶

Match labels to the data. i) Check if labels match data. ii) If they don’t, use data indicies.

Arguments: data – Data chain, to match arguments with. info – Loaded contents of info file

Return: label – Dictonary of labels, indexed with the same indicies as the data chain.

data_loader.load(infofile, datafile)[source]¶

Import the data used by SuperPlot.

Arguments: datafile - Name of chain file infofile - Name of info file

Returns: label – Dictionary with chain’s labels. data – Dictionary with chain.

data_loader.open_chain(filename)[source]¶

Open a text file or serialised data. If opening a text file, serialise data for future plots.

Arguments: filename – Name of chain file.

Returns: data – Dictionary of chain indexed with integers.

data_loader.open_data_file(filename)[source]¶

Open a text file and return dictonary of numpy arrays of data.

Arguments: filename – Name of chain file.

Returns: data – Dictionary of chain indexed with integers.

data_loader.read_info(filename)[source]¶

Read labels from a SuperBayeS style info file.
